Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Story: I stared at the calendar, my phone buzzing with messages from my family group chat. My mom’s voice echoed in my mind, “We need you with us this year. It’s been too long since we were all together.” The holiday trip was something my siblings and I had planned for months, and everyone was counting on me to be there, to laugh, to help cook, to just be a sister. But then, the email from the precinct arrived—my testimony was needed in court, the same day as our family celebration. As a police officer, I knew how important it was to act with integrity, to show up and speak the truth, no matter how inconvenient. The justice system depended on officers like me to do our part. My family expected my presence, my warmth, my support. The court expected my professionalism, my honesty, my duty. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down, my heart torn between loyalty to my family and my responsibility to the badge. I sat in silence, wrestling with the impossible choice, knowing that whatever I decided, someone would be disappointed.
